forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 3 weeks (≈21 days) until the June 17, 2025 primary; unofficial results likely the night of June 17-18.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: A competitive multi-candidate race with no clear prohibitive favorite; slightly more likely than not that someone other than Rouse wins.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: A Northern Virginia-based opponent consolidates endorsements and turnout in the vote-rich NOVA suburbs while Rouse underperforms in Hampton Roads and among statewide progressives; late polls/earned media break toward that opponent, producing a plurality loss for Rouse.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Rouse consolidates Hampton Roads and a large share of Black primary voters, adds labor and local-official support, and benefits from opposition vote-splitting in NOVA/Richmond; he wins a low-40s (or even high-30s) plurality in a crowded field.
forecast.rationale: Baseline: Virginia Democratic primaries for lieutenant governor are often multi-candidate plurality contests (e.g., 2017, 2021). In such fields, an individual candidate’s base-rate win probability approximates 1/N; with 3–4 serious contenders, that’s roughly 25–33%. Aaron Rouse is a credible, well-known state senator from Hampton Roads with the potential to raise money and assemble a geographically and demographically coherent coalition, which merits an upward adjustment from pure base rate. Countervailing factors include the outsized weight of Northern Virginia in Democratic primaries and the possibility of a well-known NOVA or Richmond-area opponent consolidating that vote. With three weeks to go, absent reliable public polling, I treat this as a competitive race in which Rouse is among the top contenders but not a prohibitive favorite. Status quo bias: If nothing significant changes, a fragmented field and NOVA turnout patterns slightly favor the field over any single candidate, keeping Rouse just below even odds. Why not higher: • Possible strong NOVA opponent, where most Democratic votes are. • Name ID statewide may lag a prior statewide nominee or long-time NOVA figure. • Plurality dynamics can cut against him if two candidates split Hampton Roads/Black vote. Why not lower: • Clear viability: regional base (Hampton Roads), potential to consolidate Black voters, strong campaign skills and fundraising potential make him more than a generic 1/N entry. • In multi-way races, a coherent regional/demographic base often suffices for a plurality. What would raise my forecast: • Credible, recent primary polling showing Rouse leading or clearly first-tier. • High-profile endorsements that signal coalition consolidation (e.g., major statewide figures, labor, key Hampton Roads blocs). • Opponents splitting NOVA/Richmond lanes or notable opponent withdrawals. • Strong late fundraising and favorable media narrative. What would lower my forecast: • Polling showing him trailing by mid-to-high single digits. • A unified NOVA-backed opponent with broad endorsements and cash lead. • Negative revelations or stumbles; weak early vote indicators from Hampton Roads. Research assistant summary: No additional information available, so this forecast leans on base rates, electoral geography, and generic candidate-quality adjustments. Note: If no Democratic primary occurs by June 30, 2025, the market would annul; that scenario currently appears very unlikely.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Aaron Rouse win the Democratic primary for lieutenant governor of Virginia in June 2025?

Question background:
Ballotpedia: [Virginia lieutenant gubernatorial election, 2025 (June 17 Democratic primary)](https://ballotpedia.org/Virginia_lieutenant_gubernatorial_election,_2025_(June_17_Democratic_primary))


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Aaron Rouse wins the 2025 Democratic primary for Lieutenant Governor of Virginia, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).

The Democratic primary election is currently scheduled for June 17, 2025. If there is no Democratic primary held before June 30, 2025, the question will be **annulled**.


Your research assistant's report says:
No additional information available.

Today is 2025-05-27.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.
